vo-dml:model.name: coords
vo-dml:model.description: This model defines objects which describe the coordinate space, coordinates within that space, and frames, which provide additional metadata regarding the origin, orientation, etc, of the coordinate space. The model also defines a coordinate system, bundling frames into associated groups.
vo-dml:model.title: Astronomical Coordinates and Coordinate Systems
vo-dml:model.author: Arnold Rots, Mark Cresitello-Dittmar, Omar Laurino

primitiveType.name: Epoch
primitiveType.description: We define epoch as a primitive data type with the expected form "<type><year>" where type = "J" or "B" for Julian or Besselian respectively, and year is expressed as a decimal year. e.g.: "B1950", "J2000.0"

enumeration.name: Handedness
enumeration.description: The handedness of a coordinate space. For most cases, this will be a fixed value in the specification of the coordinate space. We provide this element to allow this flexibility when needed. In this document, it is used in the Pixel domain.

literal.name: left
literal.description: positive x and y axes point right and up, the positive z axis points inward

literal.name: right
literal.description: positive x and y axes point right and up, the positive z axis points outward

enumeration.name: PolStateEnum
enumeration.description: Polarization states: Stokes, Circular, Linear and Vector states

literal.name: I

dataType.name: Coordinate
dataType.description: Abstract base class for the Coordinate data types which represent an absolute location within a coordinate space. Coordinates MUST refer to a coordinate system, providing additional metadata relevant to interpreting the coordinate value, and its representation.

reference.name: coordSys
reference.description: Provided additional metadata relevant to interpreting the coordinate value; for example, the spatial reference position, or time scale, axis descriptions.

dataType.name: BinnedCoordinate
dataType.description: Coordinate value type specifically intended for binned data (e.g.: pixel indexes).

attribute.name: cval
attribute.description: The binned coordinate value, expressed as an integer. e.g.: bin number, pixel index.

dataType.name: PixelIndex
dataType.description: Specialized BinnedCoordinate for the pixel domain for a 1-dimensional pixel index. PixelIndex MUST refer to a PixelCoordSystem.

dataType.name: PhysicalCoordinate
dataType.description: The most common type of coordinate value. This type is appropriate for any data whose values can be described by an ivoa:Quantity (numeric, with unit).

attribute.name: cval
attribute.description: This coordinate MUST contain a value expressed as an ivoa:Quantity.

dataType.name: Point
dataType.description: Multi-dimensional spatial coordinate. The Point MUST refer to a spatial coordinate system (SpaceSys). The coordinate values map, in order, to the axes described by the associated CoordSpace. Values for unused/undefined dimensions need not be provided.

attribute.name: axis1
attribute.description: Coordinate value along the first axis of the associated coordinate space, expressed as an ivoa:Quantity.

attribute.name: axis2
attribute.description: Coordinate value along the second axis of the associated coordinate space, expressed as an ivoa:Quantity.

attribute.name: axis3
attribute.description: Coordinate value along the third axis of the associated coordinate space, expressed as an ivoa:Quantity.

dataType.name: TimeStamp
dataType.description: This is the abstract basis for a set of simple time domain coordinates which are expected to accommodate the vast majority of use cases. All TimeStamps, by definition, exist in a standard 1-D coordinate space, with domainMin|Max of +/-Infinity. All TimeStamps MUST refer to an appropriate TimeSys.

dataType.name: TimeOffset
dataType.description: Time is given as an offset from a specific point in time (time0).

attribute.name: time
attribute.description: The TimeOffset coordinate value.

attribute.name: time0
attribute.description: The reference time from which the offset is calculated. This MUST be given as a TimeInstant (e.g.: JD, MJD, ISOTime).

dataType.name: TimeInstant
dataType.description: TimeStamps which specify a specific instant in time. We define three subtypes (ISOTime, JD, MJD), which allow users to explicitly identify the representation and interpretation of the TimeInstant.

dataType.name: JD
dataType.description: Extension of TimeInstant for time expressed in Julian days. Note that JD does not properly specify a time stamp unless it is related to a time scale and reference position. Precision can easily become an issue with JD, as the numbers tend to be large.

attribute.name: date
attribute.description: The JD coordinate value. JD dates are dimensionless, with implied units in days.

dataType.name: MJD
dataType.description: Extension of TimeInstant for time expressed in Modified Julian Days. T(MJD) = T(JD) - 2400000.5.

attribute.name: date
attribute.description: The MJD coordinate value. MJD dates are dimensionless, with implied units in days.

dataType.name: ISOTime
dataType.description: Extension of TimeInstant for time expressed as a structured datetime string. The string representation of a datetime value should follow the FITS convention for representing dates (Hanish and Farris et al, 2001). The FITS standard is effectively ISO8601 format without the 'Z' tag to indicate UTC: YYYY-MM-DD['T'hh:mm:ss[.SSS]]. The TimeScale is provided in the associated TimeFrame.

attribute.name: date
attribute.description: The ISOTime coordinate value.

dataType.name: PolCoordinate
dataType.description: Abstract head of the polarization coordinate types. Current use cases only require support for discrete polarization states, however, we include this head class to facilitate extension for other types (eg: polarization fraction and angle).

dataType.name: PolState
dataType.description: Coordinate type for discrete polarization states.

attribute.name: cval
attribute.description: The coordinate value MUST be from the PolStateEnum enumerated set.

dataType.name: RefLocation
dataType.description: RefLocation defines the origin of the spatial coordinate space. This location is represented either by a standard reference position (for which the absolute location in phase space is known by definition), or a specified point in another Spatial frame. This object is used as the origin of the SpaceFrame here, but also to specify the Spatial Reference Position (refPosition) associated with other domain Frames. For example, in the Time domain, the Spatial Reference Position indicates that the 'time' values are the time that the 'event' occured at that location, which might be different from the detector location.

dataType.name: StdRefLocation
dataType.description: An absolute a-priori known location in phase space (position and velocity). Values are selected from the StdRefPosition vocabulary. Considering that the GEOCENTER is really the only place for which we know the absolute location at all times, all other locations require the specification of a planetary ephemeris. LSR[KD] are reserved for spectral and reshift frames. TOPOCENTER (location of the observer) is special in that it assumes that the observing location is available through other means (e.g. a geographic location or an orbit ephemeris). RELOCATABLE is available for simulations. UNKNOWN should only be used if absolutely necessary.

attribute.name: position
attribute.description: Standard reference location. Values MUST be selected from the controlled vocabulary at the given URL.

dataType.name: CustomRefLocation
dataType.description: A custom reference location in phase space (position and velocity). Position and velocity are given as coordinates with an associated SpaceFrame. An epoch MAY be provided to further refine the location.

attribute.name: epoch
attribute.description: Epoch for the reference location.

attribute.name: position
attribute.description: The spatial coordinates of the reference location.

attribute.name: velocity
attribute.description: The velocity of the reference location.

objectType.name: CoordSpace
objectType.description: This object defines a domain space. i.e.: it describes the set of possible coordinate values.

composition.name: axis
composition.description: Describes an axis of the coordinate space.

objectType.name: Axis
objectType.description: The abstract parent class for all coordinate axis types. We provide concrete classes for the most common types of data, Continuous, Binned, and Discrete, but allow extension for other types as needed.

attribute.name: name
attribute.description: Freeform string, provides the name or label for the axis.

objectType.name: ContinuousAxis
objectType.description: Axis description for continuous data. This object describes the domain for a particular axis of the domain space. It allows for the specification of the legal domain range (min,max), and a flag indicating if the axis is cyclic.

attribute.name: domainMin
attribute.description: Minimum extent of the axis domain space. If not provided, the domain space is considered to have no lower bound (-INFINITY).

attribute.name: domainMax
attribute.description: Maximum extent of the axis domain space. If not provided, the domain space is considered to have no upper bound (+INFINITY).

attribute.name: cyclic
attribute.description: Flag indicating if the axis is cyclic in nature. If not provided, it is assumed to be FALSE.

objectType.name: BinnedAxis
objectType.description: Axis description for binned data, where values along the axis correspond to a bin number.

attribute.name: length
attribute.description: The length, or number of bins, along the axis.

objectType.name: DiscreteSetAxis
objectType.description: Axis type specifically intended for enumerated coordinates. Since the content and nature of this axis type is heavily dependent on the use case, we define no additional metadata here. Extensions of this type may include additional metadata relevant to the particular use cases. For example, an extension could include the allowed set of values.

objectType.name: CoordFrame
objectType.description: This is the abstract, empty, base class for all coordinate frames. Coordinate frames provide metadata associated with the coordinate domain space. Typically, this will be related to the origin and orientation of the axes, but might include any metadata which pertains to the definition of the domain.

objectType.name: GenericFrame
objectType.description: The generic coordinate frame is for cases where a domain-specific frame (e.g.: Space, Time), is not required, but the relevant reference metadata is still needed (e.g.: for Redshift or Spectral data)

attribute.name: refPosition
attribute.description: Spatial location in phase space (position and velocity) at which the observed value is considered to have been taken. This will typically be given by a standard reference position, but we allow for custom locations as well.

attribute.name: planetaryEphem
attribute.description: A planetary ephemeris MAY be provided, and SHOULD be provided whenever appropriate, to indicate which solar system ephemeris was used. If needed, but not provided, it is assumed to be "DE405"

objectType.name: SpaceFrame
objectType.description: A SpaceFrame is specified by its reference frame (orientation), and a reference position (origin). Currently only standard reference frames are allowed. An equinox MUST be provided for pre-ICRS reference frames. A planetary ephemeris MAY be provided if relevant. If needed, but not provided, it is assumed to be "DE405".

attribute.name: refPosition
attribute.description: The spatial location at which the coordinates are considered to have been determined. This model supports locations provided as either a standard reference position (e.g. GEOCENTER), or a coordinate specifying a custom location (e.g. long, lat, height ).

attribute.name: spaceRefFrame
attribute.description: The spatial reference frame. Values MUST be selected from the controlled vocabulary at the given URL.

attribute.name: equinox
attribute.description: Reference date for the frame, required for pre-ICRS reference frames.

attribute.name: planetaryEphem
attribute.description: Ephemeris file for solar system objects SHOULD be specified whenever relevant.

objectType.name: TimeFrame
objectType.description: A TimeFrame SHALL include a time scale and reference position. It MAY also include a reference direction.

attribute.name: refPosition
attribute.description: The spatial location at which the coordinate is considered to have been taken. This model supports locations provided as either a standard reference position (e.g. GEOCENTER), or a coordinate specifying a custom location (e.g. long, lat, height).

attribute.name: timescale
attribute.description: The time scale sets the reference frame. The value MUST be selected from the controlled vocabulary at the given URL.

attribute.name: refDirection
attribute.description: The reference direction is needed if the time stamps are transformed to a time frame with a different reference position. In those situations, the solar system ephemeris also comes into play. See: FITS WCS Paper IV for details, but in short: The reference direction, presumably the direction to the thing being observed, is used in conjunction with the reference position and planetary ephemeris to determine the correction applied for the path length change. To be fully useful, one also needs to know the location at which the observation was made ( i.e. the observatory location), which is not considered to be Frame metadata.

objectType.name: AstroCoordSystem
objectType.description: The AstroCoordSystem object holds a collection of component coordinate system descriptions across all represented physical domains.

composition.name: coordSys
composition.description: Coordinate system description for each physical domain (Space, Time, etc).

objectType.name: PixelCoordSystem
objectType.description: The PixelCoordSystem provides a complete description of the pixel coordinate space. It SHALL contain one PixelSpace instance describing each pixel axis.

composition.name: pixelSpace
composition.description: The pixel space completely defines the pixel coordinate axes. Each axis MUST be defined as a BinnedAxis type.

objectType.name: PixelSpace
objectType.description: A PixelSpace SHALL include one or more BinnedAxis objects describing the pixel coordinate space. A handedness value MAY be provided to specify the relative orientation of the axes.

attribute.name: handedness
attribute.description: Specifies the handedness of the coordinate space.

objectType.name: CoordSys
objectType.description: Abstract head of the coordinate system object tree.

objectType.name: PhysicalCoordSys
objectType.description: Coordinate system description for any physical domain, such as Time, Space, Redshift, Temperature, Flux, etc.

composition.name: coordSpace
composition.description: Description of the coordinate space occupied by the property.

composition.name: frame
composition.description: TODO : Missing description : please, update your UML model asap.

objectType.name: GenericSys
objectType.description: Specialized coordinate system for generic, one-dimensional domains not covered by other, more concrete objects. If a CoordSpace is not provided, it is assumed to be represented by a Standard 1-Dimensional Coordinate Space as described in Appendix B.

objectType.name: SpaceSys
objectType.description: Specialized coordinate system for the Spatial domain. This object SHOULD include an appropriate SpaceFrame. In Appendix B, we define two standard spatial coordinate space instances (Spherical and Cartesian), which may be referenced in serializations. If a CoordSpace is not provided, it is assumed to be represented by a Standard Spherical Coordinate Space.

objectType.name: TimeSys
objectType.description: Specialized coordinate system for the Temporal domain. This object SHOULD include an appropriate TimeFrame. If a CoordSpace is not provided, it is assumed to be represented by a Standard 1-Dimensional Coordinate Space as described in Appendix B.

objectType.name: PhysicalCoordSpace
objectType.description: Abstract head of coordinate spaces related to physical properties.

objectType.name: GenericCoordSpace
objectType.description: Generic, one-dimensional coordinate space suitable for use with most non-spatial properties. In Appendix B, we provide the description of a Standard 1D Coordinate Space instance which may be referenced in serializations.

objectType.name: SphericalCoordSpace
objectType.description: Spatial domain, three-dimensional spherical coordinate space. The particulars of the axis descriptions depend on the flavor of space being instantiated. In Appendix B., we provide a Standard Spherical Coordinate Space instance which applies to many Astronomical use cases. It provides the default space for SpaceSys instances, and may be referenced in serializations.

objectType.name: CartesianCoordSpace
objectType.description: Spatial domain, three-dimensional cartesian coordinate space. The particulars of the axis descriptions depend on the physical constraints of the instance. In Appendix B, we provide the description of a Standard Cartesian Coordinate Space instance which applies to many Astronomical cases, and may be referenced in serializations.
